language: East Sumbanese, Umbu Ratu Nggai dialect
Kadazan Dusun of Taginambur, Kota Belud, Sabah, Malaysia

annotation: passive, since active form does not exist: equiv. to Tagalog "niya"
fem -- much variation across pronominal functions
'ona is used also today due to influence from Tahitian.
2.He, she, it. Emphatic actor focus; him/her/it
3. He/she/it, his/her/its (Third person singular pronoun, nonfocus actor; third person singular possessive pronoun)

Note that the author of the source lexicon define the pronoun as a respectful way to refere to 'he, him' The most common 3S pronoun distinct from the 3P prounoun, has not been found in the source lexicon
vowel tones assimilates to the preceding V
almost never used - reduced form 'i' used
Third person singular pronoun, he, she, it (Sma)
object pronoun (demonstratives are used as free pronominal)
the isolated/emphatic form, but this is rarely heard in practice.
na is the common form, as a pronoun or clitic
subject only. from EAG field notes
